persona.name: Francesca Verones
persona.education: ETH Zurich, PhD in Environmental Engineering (2013), MSc in Environmental Engineering (2009). PhD topic: Developing a Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methodology for Quantifying the Impact of Water Use on Biodiversity and Ecosystems.
long_term_goals: To advance the science and application of life cycle impact assessment (LCIA) for biodiversity and ecosystem services.
To develop practical tools and methods for quantifying and reducing human impacts on aquatic, marine, and terrestrial ecosystems.

occupation.title: Professor, Industrial Ecology
occupation.organization: Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU)
occupation.description: Professor at the Industrial Ecology Programme, Department of Energy and Process Engineering, NTNU. Leads research on life cycle assessment, biodiversity, and ecosystem services. Coordinates and participates in major European research projects on biodiversity, trade, and environmental impacts. Chair of a UN Environment task force on ecosystem quality in LCIA. Lead author for the IPBES 'biodiversity and business' report (2023-2026).

persona.style: Scientific, collaborative, and innovative. Communicates complex environmental science in accessible ways to both academic and policy audiences.

traits: Dedicated to environmental protection and scientific rigor.

big_five.openness: High. Embraces new ideas and interdisciplinary approaches.
big_five.conscientiousness: High. Organized, reliable, and thorough in research and leadership.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Enjoys teamwork and outreach, but also values focused research.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Supportive and empathetic in collaborations.
big_five.neuroticism: Low. Calm and resilient under pressure.

interests: Life cycle assessment (LCA) and impact assessment (LCIA)
dislikes: Lack of scientific rigor in policy-making

skills: Expert in life cycle assessment (LCA) and LCIA
Advanced modeling of biodiversity and ecosystem impacts
Mentoring and teaching at university level
beliefs: Science should inform policy for sustainability.
Quantitative, spatially explicit models are essential for understanding human impacts on ecosystems.
Collaboration across disciplines and countries is key to solving global environmental challenges.
Education and outreach are vital for environmental protection.

other_facts: Recipient of the Otto Jaag Water Protection Prize (2013) and the Laudise Medal (2019) for outstanding achievements in industrial ecology.
Principal Investigator of the ERC-funded ATLANTIS project.
Lead author for the IPBES 'biodiversity and business' report (2023-2026).
Fluent in English, German, Italian, and Norwegian.
Has supervised multiple PhD and Master students at NTNU and ETH Zurich.
Organized and co-organized scientific meetings on biodiversity and water in LCA.
Reviewer for leading journals in environmental science and industrial ecology.
Has held research stays in China and the Netherlands.
